title: COMP/STAT212 Portfolio
text: Welcome to my online portfolio for COMP/STAT112 course taken at Macalester College. Please, use the side bar on the left for navigation.

title: Homework 01
text:
TidyTuesday Section
Explore the week’s TidyTuesday challenge. Develop a research question, then answer it through a short data story with effective visualization(s). Provide sufficient background for readers to grasp your narrative.

title: Homework 01
text:
Research Question
This week’s TidyTuesday brings insights into Brazil’s companies, curated by Marcelo Silva with data from Brazil’s open CNPJ and the Brazilian Ministry of Finance. For the assignment’s purposes, I will focus on the following research question: What distinguishes Brazil’s highest-capitalized companies from typical firms, and how do legal structure, ownership type, and formal size classifications shape access to significant capital?
Data Import

Codeinstall.packages("tidytuesdayR", repos = "https://cloud.r-project.org/")


The downloaded binary packages are in
    /var/folders/69/qbkys82d1qn4bxh5ts_647d40000gn/T//RtmpdyZRvl/downloaded_packages

Codetuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2026-01-27')
library(tidyverse)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)

companies <- tuesdata$companies
legal_nature <- tuesdata$legal_nature
qualifications <- tuesdata$qualifications
size <- tuesdata$size


Visualizations

Code# Data wrangling
companies_clean <- companies %>%
  filter(!is.na(capital_stock), !is.na(company_size), capital_stock > 0) %>%
  mutate(
    elite_threshold = quantile(capital_stock, 0.90),
    is_elite = capital_stock >= elite_threshold
  ) %>%
  
  # Get top 5 legal natures
  add_count(legal_nature, name = "legal_count") %>%
  mutate(legal_simple = if_else(
    legal_count >= sort(unique(legal_count), decreasing = TRUE)[5],
    legal_nature,
    "Other"
  ))

ggplot(companies_clean, aes(x = company_size, y = capital_stock, color = legal_simple)) +
  geom_jitter(alpha = 0.5, width = 0.2) +
  geom_hline(aes(yintercept = elite_threshold), linetype = "dashed", color = "red", size = 1) +
  scale_y_log10() +
  labs(
    title = "Capital Stock Across Company Sizes",
    subtitle = "Red line marks the top 10% threshold",
    x = "Company Size",
    y = "Capital Stock (BRL, log scale)",
    color = "Legal Nature"
  ) +
  scale_color_viridis_d() +
  theme_minimal()






Code# Data wrangling
owner_comparison <- companies %>%
  filter(!is.na(owner_qualification), !is.na(capital_stock), capital_stock > 0) %>%
  mutate(
    elite_threshold = quantile(capital_stock, 0.90),
    is_elite = if_else(capital_stock >= elite_threshold, "Elite (Top 10%)", "Other Companies")
  ) %>%
  
  # Get top 5 owner qualifications
  add_count(owner_qualification, name = "owner_count") %>%
  filter(owner_count >= sort(unique(owner_count), decreasing = TRUE)[5]) %>%
  group_by(owner_qualification, is_elite) %>%
  summarise(count = n(), .groups = "drop") %>%
  group_by(is_elite) %>%
  mutate(percent = count / sum(count) * 100)

ggplot(owner_comparison, aes(x = reorder(owner_qualification, percent), y = percent, fill = is_elite)) +
  geom_col(position = "dodge") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    title = "Who Controls the Capital?",
    subtitle = "Owner qualification patterns in elite vs. typical Brazilian companies",
    x = "Owner Qualification",
    y = "Percentage (%)",
    fill = "Company Type"
  ) +
  scale_fill_viridis_d() +
  theme_minimal()







Summary of Findings
Who controls the capital in Brazilian business?
Brazil’s CNPJ registry tracks millions of companies, including their capital stock (declared share capital). We can understand who controls significant financial resources in Latin America’s largest economy. By examining the “capital elite” (top 10% by capital stock, above R$3930456).
Does size matter for these businesses?
Our first visualization shows an interesting pattern: formal size classifications are nearly meaningless. Companies labeled “micro-enterprises” can have capital stock exceeding R$1 billion, often more than many “small-enterprises.” The elite threshold (red line) cuts across all size categories, showing that Brazil’s administrative labels don’t reflect economic reality.
However, Legal structure does matter. Limited Liability Business Companies dominate the high-capital tier, suggesting certain legal forms provide better access to serious investment.
What about ownership?
While Managing Partners control 79% of typical Brazilian firms, elite companies show much greater diversity in leadership. Administrators and Managers lead 30.5% of elite companies but only 8.7% of typical firms. Directors, Officers, and Presidents are also far more common at the top, suggesting that high-capital firms adopt more formalized corporate governance structures rather than the partnership model that dominates smaller enterprises.
So, what does that mean?
Access to capital in Brazil isn’t just about business ideas. It’s about structure. Formal size classifications may misdirect policy support, while legal form and ownership type systematically advantage certain organizational arrangements. For entrepreneurs seeking investment, these aren’t just administrative choices. They’re strategic decisions with real consequences for accessing the capital that fuels growth.

title: Cleaning SFO Weather Data
text:
Exercise
Carryout the following steps to clean and save the San Francisco Weather data. Make sure to download and add the data file to your portfolio repository as instructed.

title: Cleaning SFO Weather Data
text:
Read in the weather data in this file with the correct relative file path after you move it to the instructed location.
There is a variable that has values that don’t make sense in the data context. Figure out which variable this is and clean it up by making those values missing using na_if().
Create a variable called dateInYear that indicates the day of the year (1-365) for each case. (Jan 1 should be 1, and Dec 31 should be 365).
Create a variable called month_name that shows the 3-letter abbreviation for each case.
Save the wrangled data to the data/processed/ folder using write_csv(). Name this file weather_clean.csv. Look up the documentation for this function by typing ?write_csv in the Console. You’ll need to write an appropriate relative path.
